pullRequest.title: Http2NetworkClient Implementation
pullRequest.bodyText:
Implemented Http2NetworkClient and other http2 client related class.
Removed ClusterMapHttp2NetworkClientEndbaled, because replication http2 request is not supported.
Added RouterEnableHttp2NetworkClient, to limit http2 request in router only, for now.

Implemented Http2NetworkClient and other http2 client related class.
Removed ClusterMapHttp2NetworkClientEndbaled, becuase we can only test router based http2 request(Http2 request for replication is not supported.)
Added RouterEnableHttp2NetworkClient.

nodes.bodyText: Don't think we need to add flush here, this should just be a write method.
return here.

We should probably pass those parameter in the constructor of this adaptor, just in case later we would change those parameters to something else. Like if we ever wants to have a version 2 of ambry http2 server, than we can set the path to "/v2".
the year should be 2020

nodes.bodyText:
how much do we have to do in order to switch to retaining bytebufchannel? If we change all the requests to implement ByteBufHolder, would that be enough?
I am planning on changing the PutRequest, but just not sure what the interface would look like to suit your needs here.

return here.
and should probably do this before sending out the header.
I don't understand the header here? is this copied from the netty project?

nodes.bodyText: what are the purpose of having two queues here?
can we add pollTimeout at acquire method?
what do you want to remove it in the TODO? Keep HttpObjectAggregator seems fine to me.

nodes.bodyText: I think some time in the past, ambry supported only simple blobs, but up to 20 MB in size. I'm not sure how many blobs would be left for LinkedIn, but it might be good to set the default limit to something like 25 MB would probably be good.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -52,12 +53,23 @@
   @Default("0")
   public final int http2NettyEventLoopGroupThreads;
 
+  /**
+   * Maximum content length for a full HTTP/2 content. Used in HttpObjectAggregator.
+   * In HttpObjectAggregator, maxContentLength is not used to preallocate buffer,
+   * but it throws exception if content length great than maxContentLength
+   * TODO: Link this with blob chunk size.
+   */
+  @Config(HTTP2_MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH)
+  @Default("10 * 1024 * 1024")

nodes.bodyText: Could these be package private variables, or private with some setter methods?

Should this promise be completed from within a listener on the flush? Does the promise represent when the message is written out to network, or is it when the OutboundHandler's business logic is done?
does this class and its methods need to be public?

Could a single ConcurrentLinkedQueue satisfy these requirements? It is a lock free queue where the producer (Http2ClientResponseHandler) will be CAS-ing on one end and then sendAndPoll will be CAS-ing on the other end, so contention between the two should be quite low, I feel.
For the end condition, couldn't that just be when queue.poll() returns null?

This logic currently seems like it could lead to some busy-waiting when the system has a low request rate. In SocketNetworkClient, a timed wait is done with the select call and the wakeup call can be used by the router to unblock if some non-NetworkClient work needs to be done, whereas this implementation will return immediately if no requests are present.
In the comment above, I talked about how in the current implementation, the swapping of the queue may not be that useful. However, it could be useful if combined with a condvar monitor to signal when some new responses are ready.
I also though that LinkedBlockingQueue may no be too bad for this use case since it has separate locks for put/take operations so contention shouldn't be too bad, but this queue does not natively support wakeup without interrupting the thread. One way to wakeup in this case would be to put an empty request object in the queue (like how the server does when shutting down a RequestResponseChannel
should this be changed back to trace before merging?
We should change this to instantiate the SslFactory within NetworkClientFactory, since there can be some incompatibilities between the HTTP2 factory and the one used for RestServer.
Could you make a static method in RouterUtils to do the port selection?
final
final
What would be the pathway to removing HttpObjectAggregator? is it a bug in the Netty http2 handlers or a bug in NettyMessageProcessor?
commented code here

Generally for implementations of WritableByteChannel, I think you are supposed to copy the bytes instead of just wrapping them since ByteBuffers have no ref count system and may be reused by the writer afterwards. (This is what many of the code snippets for copying from ReadableByteChannel to WritableByteChannel do).
I think for the router, it may be okay to keep this optimization present but I did find some cases that I was a little unsure about. The suspicious case I found was PutOperation where the buffer is cleared in prepareForBuilding. I think this method is only called after a chunk is cleared. This happens when a chunk operation is completed, so for requests that we care about, it hopefully won't cause issues, but a chunk operation being completed does not necessarily mean all requests have been successfully sent out (some could be stuck in the queue).

afterCommit.message:
Http2NetworkClient Implementation

Implemented Http2NetworkClient and other http2 client related class.
Removed ClusterMapHttp2NetworkClientEndbaled, becuase we can only test router based http2 request(Http2 request for replication is not supported.)
Added RouterEnableHttp2NetworkClient.

nodes.bodyText:
I think If you do writeAndFlush here, you can remove ctx.flush in AmbrySendToHttp2Adaptor.write method.
There is one more thing to consider, is that when the write method fails, it's not going to be captured by anything. We need to deal with that.

Yeah, the NettyMessageProcessor doesn't expect a FullHttpRequest, it expects different http components. If we can get rid of NettyMessageProcessor here, I would totaly vote for it. NettyMessageProcessor does look like over complicated processor that was designed for frontend.
in the ambry server, we don't have multiple chunks, we don't have requests or response larger than 4MB. Lots of logic in the frontend just don't make too much sense in the ambry server.
minor: add Count to the end of this metric name for consistency
Add check for closed channel to this method?
extra empty line here
Would this log every time a connection is closed? It may be worth setting this to debug and also include the remote hostname if possible.
this isn't a linked list any more.
minor: change this to say 800 ms

We do have requests and responses larger than 4 MB for replication batch-gets (and that period of time last year when we ran with 8 MB chunks), so there can be value from streaming. However, a lot of things, such as the way we prefetch blobs in the server, to get tangible benefit (other than abstract goals like sharing code btwn frontend/server) out of NettyMessageProcessor or similar pieces.
